G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 218, §19, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the Boston Municipal Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a78.proposition: Venue is proper in the Dorchester Division pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §8, because the leased premises and the underlying transactions occurred within this division.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: The tenancy is an at-will or fixed-term residential tenancy governed by G.L. c. 186 and the Massachusetts common law of landlord-tenant.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7127A.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the heating system in working order deprived Plaintiff of the quiet enjoyment of her dwelling and rendered the premises unfit for human habitation under G.L. c. 111, §127A and related housing code regulations.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, every residential tenancy agreement contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, ensuring that a tenant shall not be disturbed in the use and enjoyment of her rented premises by the acts or omissions of the landlord.

105 C.M.R. 410.201.proposition: Defendant’s conduct is further prohibited under 105 C.M.R. 410.201 and 410.201(A), which require that heating facilities be maintained in good working order and capable of maintaining a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and 64°F otherwise.

410.201(A).proposition: Defendant’s conduct is further prohibited under 105 C.M.R. 410.201 and 410.201(A), which require that heating facilities be maintained in good working order and capable of maintaining a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and 64°F otherwise.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The loss of adequate heat constitutes a substantial interference with the use of leased premises, triggering liability under the statute. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff concerns noise from a lounge causing constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; it does not address lack of heat or loss of adequate heat. The only reference to heat is in a citation to another case (Charles E. Burt) as an example of constructive eviction, but Blackett itself does not establish any rule about loss of adequate heat constituting substantial interference. Thus, it does not directly support the specific heat-related proposition for which it is cited.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services).

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The loss of adequate heat constitutes a substantial interference with the use of leased premises, triggering liability under the statute. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court describes the lack of heat as seriously impairing the character and value of the leased premises and imposes statutory quiet enjoyment liability without requiring intent. This directly supports the proposition that loss of adequate heat is a substantial interference triggering liability under the statute.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The loss of adequate heat constitutes a substantial interference with the use of leased premises, triggering liability under the statute. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004).
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses substantial interferences with tenancy under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but in the context of a long-standing ventilation defect, moisture, foul odors, and a resulting fire—not loss of adequate heat. Nowhere does the court mention heat, heating failures, or lack of adequate heat as the basis for liability. Thus, while Jablonski supports that serious code violations causing substantial impairment trigger quiet enjoyment liability, it does not specifically address or establish that loss of adequate heat constitutes such an interference.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem — a serious code violation — for over nine years… On these facts found by the judge, we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that persistent defective conditions—even when partial or intermittent—constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the landlord has notice and fails to act effectively. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment generally and confirms that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects can violate § 14, but it does not address “persistent defective conditions— even when partial or intermittent.” The case is about whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself, creates § 14 liability and holds that at least negligence with notice is required; it does not involve, characterize, or analyze persistent, partial, or intermittent defective conditions as a basis for quiet enjoyment. Thus it does not substantively support the specific proposition stated.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that persistent defective conditions—even when partial or intermittent—constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the landlord has notice and fails to act effectively. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: Berman addresses breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement where the tenant suffered intermittent and then complete loss of heat and hot water, but it does not analyze or apply the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion is framed entirely in terms of warranty of habitability, strict liability, and timing of rent abatement, not quiet enjoyment or the standards for that covenant. Thus, while it supports that persistent defective conditions can breach the warranty of habitability once the landlord has notice, it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. … We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.proposition: The failure of the landlord to comply with housing code standards constitutes evidence of breach of G.L. c. 186, §14. See Hemingway v. O’Brien, 363 Mass. 359 (1973); Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1975).
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.case_name: Board of Appeals of Hanover v. Housing Appeals Comm.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.support_reasoning: This Hemingway v. O’Brien decision concerns G.L. c. 40B (the anti‑snob‑zoning statute), zoning powers, and the Housing Appeals Committee. It does not involve landlord‑tenant relations, G.L. c. 186, §14, housing code standards, or breach of quiet enjoyment or repair obligations. The proposition about housing code violations evidencing a breach of G.L. c. 186, §14 is therefore not addressed or supported by this opinion; it is instead discussed in Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway and McKenna v. Begin.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.relevant_excerpt: The opinion throughout addresses the powers and procedures under G. L. c. 40B, §§20‑23, zoning, and the Housing Appeals Committee; it contains no discussion of G. L. c. 186, §14, landlord obligations, or housing code violations. There is thus no passage relevant to the claimed proposition about breach of G. L. c. 186, §14.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: The failure of the landlord to comply with housing code standards constitutes evidence of breach of G.L. c. 186, §14. See Hemingway v. O’Brien, 363 Mass. 359 (1973); Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1975).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses housing code violations as part of an implied contractual obligation and as a basis for adjusting rent liability, but it never mentions G.L. c. 186, §14 or treats code violations as evidence of a breach of that statute. The analysis is framed in terms of implied agreements/warranties and rent abatement, not statutory remedies under §14, so it does not directly support the specific proposition that housing code noncompliance constitutes evidence of a §14 breach.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1975)
McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (.proposition: The failure of the landlord to comply with housing code standards constitutes evidence of breach of G.L. c. 186, §14. See Hemingway v. O’Brien, 363 Mass. 359 (1973); Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1975).
McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability and references the State Sanitary Code and related statutes, but it does not construe or apply G.L. c. 186, §14, nor does it state that housing code violations constitute evidence of a breach of that statute. Its analysis is framed in terms of the implied warranty of habitability and damages, not the remedies or elements under c. 186, §14. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed, even though it is consistent with Hemingway’s general approach to code violations and habitability.
McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (.relevant_excerpt: “Under the formula applied by the judge, a rental of defective premises would be tantamount to a waiver of the statutory provisions for enforcement of the State Sanitary Code and the landlord’s implied obligation to let and maintain the premises in a habitable condition. Such an agreement would be against public policy and void (G. L. c. 111, § 127K, inserted by St. 1968, c. 404, § 2) and would violate the interdiction against waiver of an implied warranty of habitability (at least insofar as it is based on the State Sanitary Code and local health regulations).”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Plaintiff’s situation is further supported by Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987), and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), holding that repeated failures to correct essential problems such as lack of heat or water violate quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: Young v. Patukonis does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment or hold that repeated failures to correct essential conditions like lack of heat or water violate quiet enjoyment. The opinion instead addresses (1) the regulatory requirement of a *written* agreement to shift responsibility for heat and hot water, (2) security deposit penalties, (3) rent control overcharges, (4) habitability damages, and (5) c. 93A applicability. It is therefore not proper authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling “shall” supply heat and hot water “except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.” … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Plaintiff’s situation is further supported by Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987), and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), holding that repeated failures to correct essential problems such as lack of heat or water violate quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition claims Simon v. Solomon held that repeated failures to correct essential problems like lack of heat or water violate quiet enjoyment. Simon does involve repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions, and it construes G.L. c. 186, § 14’s quiet‑enjoyment language broadly, but the court ultimately vacated the tenant’s quiet enjoyment damages as duplicative and focused the holding on emotional distress and habitability, not specifically on lack of heat or water. The case discusses interference with quiet enjoyment conceptually but is not a clean holding that repeated failure to fix essential services such as heat or water, per se, violates quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.… Section 14… provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises.… The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages… suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses… within the scope of statutory recovery.”
